title: GOP Braces for Nevada Caucus Mayhem on Tuesday
content:
LAS VEGAS—After a confusing start , with a big turnout of voters and some absent volunteers , Saturday ’ s Democratic caucuses in Nevada fell into regular order , delivering a victory for Hillary Clinton over Bernie Sanders less than three hours after the voting began .
Republicans , who hold their caucuses in Nevada on Tuesday , are bracing for a much tougher night . Party officials here and in Washington fear a repeat of the 2012 debacle in which it took officials days to count just 33,000 ballots and certify that Newt Gingrich finished second behind Mitt Romney .
The combination of a disorganized and underfunded state Republican Party , decentralized responsibility for reporting results and an electorate that has never seen a competitive presidential caucus has GOP officials bracing for logistical nightmares Tuesday .
Unlike in Iowa , where the state parties recruited Microsoft to build a high-tech caucus results reporting system , or New Hampshire and South Carolina , where state elections officials conduct the primaries , in Nevada county GOP officials have responsibility for holding local caucuses , counting ballots and reporting results .
Here in Clark County , which includes greater Las Vegas and 73 % of the state ’ s population , Republican volunteers at each of the 36 caucus locations will count ballots by hand , write the results on an envelope , take a photograph of the envelope and text the photo to Ed Williams , the Clark County Republican Party chairman , and to state GOP officials . The state party is also allowing the Associated Press to monitor the results as they come in from precincts ; in 2012 the party announced results itself on Twitter .
“ The official number will be whatever is photographed , ” Mr. Williams said .
The new reporting method should be an improvement over 2012 , Mr. Williams said , when officials at some Las Vegas-area caucus sites packed ballots in their cars and drove them to the county party headquarters , where they were counted .
At the same time county officials elsewhere in the state emailed their results to state headquarters in Microsoft Excel spreadsheets—but because many precincts had been recently renumbered , columns didn ’ t line up properly , forcing manual counting of the vote totals during the days after the caucuses .
Before any caucus votes are cast , senior Republicans in Washington are suggesting that if Nevada ’ s 2012 problems resurface , it will be at risk of losing its place in the front of the party ’ s presidential nominating calendar .
That “ puts a huge amount of pressure to get it right this time or lose their place in the rotation in the favored four states , ” said Ben Ginsberg , a longtime GOP election lawyer who worked for the George W. Bush and Mitt Romney campaigns .
While expressing public optimism the caucus process will run smoothly , the leading campaigns here are preparing for the worst .
Texas Sen. Ted Cruz ’ s campaign has instructed supporters to place their cellphones in the video mode as they enter caucus sites and record anything that looks suspicious , according to a person familiar with the matter .
The state party is so stretched for volunteers that it has asked elected officials to volunteer at some caucus sites .
“ Most Nevadans have not been involved before , “ said Victoria Seaman , a Republican in the state assembly who agreed to volunteer at a caucus in her Las Vegas district . ” It ’ s going to be messy unless we get people to come out and that is why our team is asking us to get involved . It ’ s so confusing . ”
Republican National Committee officials , aiming to avoid a repeat of the 2012 embarrassment , are subsidizing a voter registration program , caucus trainings and a field staff of more than a dozen who will remain in place through the November general election .
“ As with all of our state parties , the RNC is here to be a resource and provide support , ” said RNC spokeswoman Sara Sendek , who is handling press inquiries for the state party . “ But ultimately this is the Nevada Republican Party ’ s caucus where Republicans in Nevada will make their voices heard . ”
The RNC and 2016 presidential candidates are bankrolling the state party . Of the $ 429,521 the Nevada GOP raised during the last seven months of 2015 , more than half came in direct contributions from the Republican National Committee and the $ 12,500 filing fees presidential candidates paid to appear on the caucus ballot , according to campaign finance documents filed with the Nevada secretary of state ’ s office .
Another $ 50,000 came from Huntsman International , the company founded by Jon M. Huntsman Sr. , whose son was governor of Utah and ran for president in 2012 . Right to Rise PAC , the leadership political-action committee backing Jeb Bush ’ s campaign , gave the party $ 10,000 .
Nevada GOP Chairman Michael McDonald didn ’ t respond to repeated messages left on his cellphone .
Tuesday ’ s caucuses will be just the third for Republicans since Nevada moved close to the front of the presidential nominating calendar . In both 2008 and 2012 Mr. Romney , powered by support from the state ’ s Mormon population , won with twice as much support as the second-place candidates .
“ It ’ s not a natural course of politics as usual and voting as usual as everybody ’ s used to here , ” said James Smack , a former Nevada GOP chairman . “ It ’ s going to be scratchy no matter what . We ’ re not like Iowa , where people have been doing this since the dawn of time . ”
There is plenty of opportunity for confusion . Not all of the state ’ s caucuses start at the same time . Some start at 5 p.m. local time , others an hour later . In Clark County voting must be complete by 8:30 p.m. , to give officials a head start counting ballots . Other parts of the state will allow voting until 9 p.m .
Unlike Nevada Democrats , Republicans here forbid same-day caucus registration , a practice that has been a boon for the state ’ s Democratic registration but has been rebuffed by Republicans fearful of voter fraud .
The state GOP set a Feb. 13 deadline to register with the party to participate in the caucuses . By contrast , Iowa Republicans allowed caucus-goers to register on site at the state ’ s Feb. 1 contest . About 10 % of the state ’ s 170,000 caucus-goers registered on site the day of the caucuses , according to Iowa GOP spokesman Charlie Szold .
Ryan Erwin , the Nevada director for Jeb Bush ’ s campaign , said there is “ room for chaos ” in the state ’ s caucus process and predicted a messy outcome no matter what happens . “ This is the home of the conspiracy theory , ” Mr. Erwin said .
The assumption from political professionals here is that Donald Trump will do very well , but there is no reliable public polling of Nevada and the state party didn ’ t maintain a list of 2012 caucus-goers , so there is no way for campaigns or pollsters to target people most likely to caucus .
“ I don ’ t think the state party has a great organization , ” said Sig Rogich , a Las Vegas marketing official who was the chief media adviser for the 1988 and 1992 George H.W . Bush presidential campaigns . “ There ’ s been no outreach from the state party.…It ’ s confusing to people , where to go , how to get there . They don ’ t know how it works . ”
Turnout is expected to be very small , about 10 % to 15 % of the state ’ s 400,000 registered Republicans . About 44,000 people voted in the state ’ s 2008 caucuses and the total dropped by a quarter four years later . Even the most optimistic Nevada GOP scenarios envision turnout to be far less than the 65,000 people who voted in last week ’ s primary for mayor of Milwaukee .
“ There ’ s still a good deal of confusion on the part of the general public on how it works , ” said former Nevada Gov . Bob List . “ We really should have a primary here so that everyone can participate in a reasonable way . ”
